Award.AwardTitle: EARS: Collaborative Research: Spectrum Sensing for Coexistence of Active and Passive Radio Services
Award.AbstractNarration:
This EARS (Enhancing Access to the Radio Spectrum) program was founded in response to the 2010 Presidential Memorandum on Unleashing the Wireless Broadband Revolution mandated by Congress as part of the National Broadband Plan. It was referenced in 2010 State of the Union and later on the Middle Class Tax Relief and Job Creation Act of 2012 (More than 1/3 of the bill deals with radio spectrum), the PCAST 2012 Report [President's Council of Advisors on Science and Technology] (which calls for vastly increased use of spectrum sharing) and the 2013 Presidential memo (Expanding America's Leadership in Wireless Innovation). The aim of this program is to identify bold new concepts with the potential to contribute to significant improvements in the efficiency of radio spectrum utilization, protection of passive sensing services, and in the ability for traditionally underserved Americans to benefit from current and future wireless-enabled goods and services. The impact is large on the economics of the Nation as seen on the last FCC bidding of 65MHz of the spectrum for over $45 billion early in 2015. It will enable access to science, engineering, industry, civilian and military users of the RF spectrum.

Effective use of radio spectrum is coveted by both active services (e.g., cellular, radar, wireless internet) and passive services (e.g., radio astronomy service (RAS) and earth exploration satellite service (EESS)). It has led to an increasing tension between the growing demand for greater spectrum use by active radios and the pressing need for quiet spectrum by passive systems. The first and foremost step towards alleviating this tension is to monitor the radio frequency environment at high resolution in time, space, frequency, and even some appropriately defined feature space. Although the spectrum monitoring issue has undergone extensive research and radio frequency interference (RFI) detection has been fervently investigated in the remote sensing communities, only limited efforts exist in examining spectrum monitoring from the perspectives of both active and passive systems to conscientiously support coexistence. To support peaceful coexistence on radio spectrum, this project aims to develop efficient spectrum monitoring techniques that provide deep understanding and technological enablers for future spectrum management in the growing presence of active and passive radio services.

Advanced signal processing techniques will be developed to provide high-resolution spectrum sensing at short sensing time, and optimal sensing resource allocation schemes will be investigated to maximize the payoffs of the sensing budget. The proposed research on spectrum sensing will inform and advance the RFI detection and management in support of increased societal and scientific returns from RAS and EESS investments. The developed techniques can also be leveraged by cognitive radio networks for dynamic spectrum sharing, impacting practices of the services like cellular data and Internet of things (IoT). Graduate and undergraduate students will benefit from the unique interdisciplinary nature of this research, especially through interactions with the scientists at the Arecibo Observatory, and the hands-on experience with its 305 m telescope.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Effective use of radio spectrum is coveted by both active services (e.g., cellular, radar, wireless internet) and passive services (e.g., radio astronomy service and earth exploration satellite service). There is an increasing tension between the growing demand for greater spectrum use by active radios and the pressing need for quiet spectrum by passive systems. To alleviate this tension and support peaceful coexistence on radio spectrum, this project develops efficient spectrum monitoring techniques that provide deep understanding and technological enablers for future spectrum management in the growing presence of active and passive radio services. Advanced signal processing techniques are developed to provide high-resolution spectrum sensing at short sensing time, and optimal sensing resource allocation schemes are investigated to maximize the payoffs of the sensing budget.

Intellectual merit: The project outcomes include a set of accurate and efficient techniques for the detection of radio frequency interference (RFI). To characterize RFI, useful statistical features in the spectral domain are identified and tested, such as cyclostationarity, cumulant statistics and spectral Kurtosis etc., which are shown to be effective for separating man-made signals from astronomical signals of interest.

The first major outcome is the development of a compressive statistical sensing (CSS) framework for sensing problems of relevance to spectrum coexistence. Here the problem space is huge, the signal of interest is sparse and weak, and the sampling and computational resources are limited. The CSS framework allows to directly extract the identified useful statistical features from compressive measurements, leading reduced sensing costs and time. Further, when line spectrum estimation is of interest, an atomic norm minimization (ANM) scheme is introduced. Based on covariance statistics, a decoupled-ANM (D-ANM) scheme is developed for frequency identification from high-dimensional problems. D-ANM enables fast feature extraction using a drastically reduced sensing time and data samples. The saving in sensing time and data samples are particularly prominent for large-scale problems such as in space-spectral sensing.

The second major outcome is the development of a new approach to line spectrum estimation from quadratic measurements. This problem bears some resemblance to the phase retrieval problem, in which the signal has to be reconstructed from amplitude measurements, without phase information. Focusing on the line spectral analysis problem, the developed technique utilizes the underlying signal geometric structure to enable optimal reconstruction from a considerably reduced number of quadratic measurements within a short sensing time. Both the number of required measurements and the computational complexity are much lower than the start of the art. The proposed framework is general enough to deal with many forms of quadratic measurements, including correlations, cyclic correlations and amplitude only.

The third major outcome is the development of new results on reconstructing higher-order statistics (HOS) from compressive measurements in order to detect and analyze astronomical signals with HOS characteristics. In particular, a compressive 3rd-order cumulant sensing (C3CS) approach is proposed, which accurately reconstructs the third-order cumulant from compressive measurements even in the absence of sparsity. Further, for 1-D cumulant slice reconstruction, optimal sparse samplers are designed for building practical spectrum sensing devices. The proposed minimum sparse ruler samplers are optimal and maximally conserve sampling resources in terms of the number of samples (and hence sampling energy) needed for reconstruction. These results advance the state of the art on CSS, so that this powerful compressive sensing framework can be broadly applied for efficient extraction of useful higher-order statistics for the first time.

The fourth major outcome is the testing and refinement of the CSS framework for RFI detection by analyzing real-world radio astronomy data. CSS-based solutions are shown to enable robust and efficient detection of the RFI frequency bands present in the data, which is measured by receiver operating characteristic. They lead to fast and computationally efficient identification of RFI-free frequency regions in wideband radio astronomy observations.

Broader impacts: The outcomes advance the understanding and techniques for radio frequency interference detection and management in support of increased societal and scientific returns from the passive service investments such as radio astronomy service and earth exploration satellite service. The project has developed efficient feature extraction algorithms for high-dimensional signal sensing at super resolution and affordable sensing resources. By substantially lowering the sensing costs in time and complexity, this project could impact the practical implementation of spectrum monitoring systems for both active and passive radio services. The developed technologies can be leveraged by cognitive radio networks for dynamic spectrum sharing, which would impact the practice of active services like cellular data and Internet of things. The outcomes of this project also support spectrum regulation and enforcement via technical innovations in spectrum sensing and signal processing.

This project provides direct training opportunities for PhD students and postdoctoral researchers, who will enter the workforce with well-developed skills in STEM. The knowledge acquired in this project has been conscientiously incorporated into classroom teaching to enhance students’ learning experience.
